item.title: US Secretary of Defense claims US is not leaving Iraq despite letter stating otherwise---HOLD
item.dc:creator: jross
item.content:encoded: US Secretary of Defense Mark Esper told reporters on Monday that the US has no plans to evacuate troops out of Iraq, despite circulation of a draft letter that suggests otherwise. In his statement, Esper clarified that the letter was “poorly worded” and was meant to indicate troop repositioning, not removal. Tensions have increased between the US and Iraq after President Trump ordered drone strikes in Baghdad, Iraq on Friday, killing top Iranian military commander Qassem Soleimani. Following his death, Iran demanded the US remove troops from Iraq. On Monday, Iraq’s parliament formally passed a resolution to this effect. It appeared that the US Military began efforts to remove troops from the area. In a draft letter that has cause some confusion comes from the US military, addressed to Iraq officials, informing them that troop movements will occur due to Iraq’s recent vote to expel US forces. Specifically, the letter said US forces would use helicopters and other measures to “ensure the movement out of Iraq” is conducted safely. While the letter isn’t signed, the letter appears to originate from the office of Brigadier General William H. Seely. Addressing reporters on Monday, Esper denied the US is removing troops from the area. Instead, the Secretary of Defense claimed the origin of the letter is unknown and was meant to simply inform Iraqi leaders that there will be increased in movement of US troops due to repositioning. Pentagon Press Secretary Alyssa Farah confirmed this US policy position in a tweet, stating “There has been no change in US policy with regard to our force presence in Iraq.”

item.title: Teva Pharmaceuticals settles for $54 Million over illegal kickback allegations involving doctor bribery---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: James E. Miller, attorney representing relators, whistleblowers Charles Arnstein and Hossam Senousy announced on Monday that Teva Pharmaceuticals agreed to settle alleged violations of the False Claims Act (FCA) based on a complaint filed by the whistleblowers in 2013. Teva allegedly used “speaker programs” to pay physician speakers unlawful compensation in order "to influence the prescription writing of neurologists with respect to Azilect (a Parkinson’s Disease drug) and Copaxone (a Multiple Sclerosis drug)" which violates the False Claims Act, 31 U.S.C. §§ 3729-3733, and the Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS), 42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b. It is a felony under AKS to "knowingly or willingly" solicit, receive, offer or pay any remuneration (including kickbacks, bribes, or rebates) to induce such person to recommend purchasing, leasing, or ordering good, facility, service or item for which payment may be made in whole or in part under a Federal health care program. According to the complaint, Teva made such illegal payments to physician speakers to wrote prescriptions for the two drugs, Azilect and Copaxone that were filled at pharmacies. Pharmacies then submitted claims for reimbursement to health care programs.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York denied Teva's summary judgement motion in February 2019 and allowed the case to proceed to trial. The court said that the statute "does not require evidence of negotiations with the party receiving the kickback," and held that "payor must offer or pay ‘with the intent to gain influence over the reason or judgment of a person making referral decisions.'"

item.title: Federal judge refuses to block California's 'gig labor' law from impacting freelancers---HOLD
item.dc:creator: tgillett
item.content:encoded: A federal judge in California denied a request for a temporary restraining order against Assembly Bill 5, which changes how companies can classify independent contractors. Two organizations representing freelance reporters and photographers sought the order to prevent harm to their members while other challenges to AB 5 are heard by the court. In order to retain their freelance status, writers and photographers under the law will be capped at submitting 35 pieces of content per publication per year - any more than that would require them to be classified as employees, resulting in higher costs for their employers. The American Society for Journalists and Authors and the National Press Photographers Association argued that the cap is too low and would result in some freelancers who are regular contributors to publications hitting it within just a few months. Not only will freelancers lose work, the organizations argued, the law also places a substantial burden on their free speech rights. However, Judge Philip Gutierrez denied the request, citing the fact that while the law was signed in September, the plaintiffs waited until December 17 to file suit, and filed the request for the restraining order on December 31, one day before the law was scheduled to go into effect. Given that restraining orders are "drastic remedies," a strong showing of urgency or necessity is required before a court will grant them. "Plaintiffs’ delay belies their claim that there is an emergency," the judge concluded. A full hearing on their request is scheduled for March.

item.title: 5th Circuit denies usage of res judicata in removal proceedings case---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: The 5th Circuit denied the petitioner's appeal to stay removal proceedings on Thursday. The Petitioner had argued that the removal proceedings violated the principal of res judicata, as the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) had previously attempted to remove the Petitioner. The Petitioner, a permanent resident from Mexico, was convicted of evading arrest with a car and burglarizing a house in December 2014. The former offense occurred in November 2013, and the latter in March 2014. While in state custody, the DHS charged him with removability under on the grounds that evading arrest with a car counted as an aggravated felony and he had been sentenced to at least one year in prison. The removal proceedings were upheld by an Immigration Judge. The Board of Immigration Appeals terminated the Petitioner's removal holding that the relevant statue's definition of "aggravated felony" was unconstitutionally vague. This is in line the 5th Circuit's decision in US v Gonzalez-Longoria. In response, the DHS brought new removal proceedings against the petitioner, this time basing it on the burglary conviction. The Petitioner argued that the principal of res judicata prevented the DHS from bringing new charges against him. He based his argument that the underlying conviction already existed the first time, and that by not basing removal proceedings on it then the DHS had waved its right to do so. The 5th Circuit ruled that res judicata did not apply in this situation due to the unrelated nature of the two offenses. This under lying fact also did not bar the DHS from bringing removal proceedings a second time because the petitioner's convictions did not rely on the same set of facts.

item.title: California Commission finds appellate judge engaged in misconduct---HOLD
item.dc:creator: abloomberg
item.content:encoded: The California Commission on Judicial Performance released their report on the inquiry in Justice Jeffery W. Johnson this week, which found the Second Circuit Appellate Judge guilty of prejudicial misconduct and improper actions.  Johnson faced ten counts of misconduct for inappropriate conduct towards 17 women, after-hours intoxication while acting on behalf of the court, and improper demeanor towards colleagues. The report found Johnson guilty on 9 out of 10 counts, the remaining count was barred by the statute of limitations. The report, based on 17 days of testimony from over 100 witnesses, details events that primarily take place over a nine-year span from 2009-2018. The women subjected to the inappropriate conduct include: two Court of Appeal justices, two judicial assistants, two California Highway Patrol officers, six private attorneys, and two federal court employees. The misconduct ranges from, "overly familiar compliments to highly offensive touching and vulgar, sexually explicit statements." Several of the incidents of misconduct towards women occurred while Johnson was visibly intoxicated and acting as a Court of Appeal justice. Finally, Johnson engaged in improper actions when he publicly commented on another Justice's body and engaged with other justices and court staff in a manner which was "disrespectful and discourteous", including calling staff "stupid" and their work "horrible" and "ignorant". Johnson's defenses to the charges misconduct towards the 17 women relied on attempts to discredit the witnesses as unreliable and their testimony as incredible. He denies acting improperly towards his colleagues or becoming visibly intoxicated, suggesting the latter was the result of diabetic symptoms.  The Commission rejected these defenses. Further, they cited a number of aggravating factors such as Johnson's untruthful testimony, the likelihood that he "suffers from an untreated alcohol problem", focus on blaming others, and the large number of victims. If the panel upholds the findings at the next hearing on March 18, it will be the first time the Commission removes an appellate justice for misconduct.

item.title: Taiwan president wins second term in landslide---HOLD
item.dc:creator: tgillett
item.content:encoded: Tsai Ing-wen of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won a second term as president of Taiwan in Saturday's election. She soundly defeated leading contender Han Kuo-yu of the Kuomingtang (KMT) party, with over 57% of voters casting their ballot for her. The DPP also maintained control of the Taiwan legislature. Voter turnout was at 74%, up from 66% four years ago when Ms. Tsai was first elected. In 2016, 6.6 million people voted for her, while in Saturday's election 8.1 million people voted to keep her in office, versus just 5.5 million voting for Mr. Han. The two opposing candidates differed greatly when it came to the major issue of China. Ms. Tsai and the DPP seek independence for the island nation, while Mr. Han and the KMT campaigned under a message of greater unity with mainland China. China's president Xi Jinping has offered a plan of "one government, two systems," by which it governs the former colonial territories of Hong Kong and Macau, and has promised that Taiwan could keep its political and social freedoms if it reunifies with the mainland. However, the heavy ongoing crackdown against anti-government protestors in Hong Kong seems to have driven the Taiwanese people away from thoughts of reunification. In light of Ms. Tsai's overwhelming reelection it remains to be seen whether China will try a more conciliatory approach to Taiwan, or if it will turn to more forceful measures to bring the island under its control.

item.title: House passes PFAS legislation to increase water standards---HOLD
item.dc:creator: enapoleon
item.content:encoded:
The House of Representative passed a bill on Friday requiring the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to create a drinking water standard for per and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). PFAS are known as forever chemicals because they take a long time to decompose into the environment after being released from industrial products such as a firefighting foam and cleaning products. This new bill requires the EPA to designate PFAS as hazardous substances within a year of their discovery, allowing contamination sites to be eligible for federal cleanup funding. In addition, the bill requires both testing of drinking water and the federal government to impose a maximum contamination level for PFAS in water. Representative Debbie Dinkle, a sponsor of PFAS Action of 2019, stated that this is an issue affecting  the American people as a whole and that many are unaware of the negative consequences PFAS have on one’s health.
PFAS is a clear threat to human health and our environment. Experts believe 99 percent of Americans have some level of PFAS in their blood—and most don’t even know. These harmful forever chemical[s] persist everywhere and are linked to cancer, liver disease, thyroid dysfunction and decreased fertility. Exposures to contaminated water, air and soil kill more people than smoking, hunger, natural disasters, was, AIDs, or malaria.
This issue will likely not be taken up by the Republican controlled Senate. Prior to the vote, Republican Representative Andy Harris stated, “Look, obviously, the EPA is charged with making sure out water is safe. I trust the EPA. I’m not sure that we need the Democrat House looking over our shoulder to figure out how it’s done. I leave it to the professionals of the EPA.”

item.title: U.S. Labor Department rule makes suing corporations with franchise wage violations more difficult---HOLD
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. Labor Department filed a new rule Monday that narrows the term "employer" for wage disputes under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Under the new rule, corporations with franchises will no longer be considered a joint employer of franchise employees. This change would limit a franchise employee's lawsuit for claimed wages under the FLSA to only the franchise owner. The employee could not pursue the wages from the franchise's corporation. The Labor Department concluded that its new rule:
Helps bring clarity to the current judicial landscape, where different courts are applying different joint employer tests that have resulted in inconsistent treatment of similar worker situations, uncertainty for organizations, and increased compliance and litigation costs; [r]educes the chill on organizations who may be hesitant to enter into certain relationships or engage in certain kinds of business practices for fear of being held liable for counterparty employees over which they have insignificant control; [b]etter grounds the Department’s interpretation of joint employer status in the text of the FLSA; and [i]s responsive to the current public and Congressional interest in the joint employer issue.
This rule is a stark turn from the 2014 Obama Administration interpretive rule that allowed for franchise employees to sue both the franchise and corporation in wage disputes.  The new rule takes effect upon its publishing to the Federal Register Thursday.

item.title: Law school graduate wins discharge of student debt---HOLD
item.dc:creator: vnegron
item.content:encoded: On January 7 the US Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of NY allowed the discharge of a law student's school debt on the theory that forcing the student to pay would have been "punitive". The defendant Kevin Jared Rosenberg graduated from law school and after making payments in varying amounts over the past ten years still owes over 220,000. Judge Morris stated in the opinion that she would apply the often misused Brunner test in the manner originally intended for it to be applied. This means first looking at the person's assets and discerning if they "maintain the minimal standard of living". In this case, it is found that Rosenberg can't because his income is already negative every month. The second prong od the est is whether the person's financial situation will maintain the same during the repayment. This is satisfied as the 10-year repayment timeframe has passed. Finally, the test seeks to find if the debtor has made a good faith effort to pay which the Morris finds satisfied since Rosenberg was current on his loan missing only 16 payments in 13 years and asked for forbearance when he could not pay prior to filing for bankruptcy. This decision is very important because if it survives on appeal it could allow more people who file for bankruptcy to discharge their student loans and regain their financial security. For Rosenberg, he says he is not happy just relieved to not be burdened anymore.

item.title: Mexico Attorney General presents criminal justice reforms to legislators---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ahursh
item.content:encoded: On Thursday, Mexican officials and Attorney General Alejandro Gertz presented lawmakers there with an ambitious proposal for overhauling the country's criminal justice system. The measures will be formally set forth next month, but legislators got an initial look at the plans developed under President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador’s government that came into power in 2018. The reforms could represent dramatic steps to address violence and corruption in Mexico, but they will require constitutional amendments, new criminal laws, and altered administrative procedures, among other things.  Two features of the proposed reform have to do with wiretapping phone communications and security cooperation with the United States. Legal challenges that currently prevent extradition for criminal suspects would be weakened. Additionally, amendments to criminal procedural requirements would allow the use of wiretapped private communications as evidence towards convictions. Limits to this evidence have stymied criminal prosecutions in the past.

item.title: Facebook must turn over app records, Massachusetts court orders---HOLD
item.dc:creator: gkolencik
item.content:encoded: Justice Brian Davis of the Massachusetts Superior Court ordered that Facebook is to turn over material in regards to third-party apps that may have misused the data of Facebook users. Attorney General Maura Healey successfully proved that she had a substantial need for the material in order to conduct further investigation into Facebook’s privacy practices. Although Facebook argued that the information was protected under attorney client privilege, it was ultimately found that, “the attorney client privilege does not extend to any underlying facts or other information learned by Facebook during the [App Developer Investigation].” Additionally, the Court found that the materials are not protected under work-product privilege--a privilege that protects information prepared by attorneys in anticipation of litigation or for trial. The case began in March of 2018 when Healey sought to investigate Facebook further after information was released that Cambridge Analytica--a political consulting firm--was given access to the data of millions of Facebook users by Facebook. Significantly, the information gathered was used “to target Facebook users with campaign messaging that [benefited] Cambridge Analytica’s clients in the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election.” Facebook is now reviewing its options and the potential of appeal.

item.title: UN Human Rights Committee issues decision in climate refugee case---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: Though UN's Human Rights Committee (UN) ruled against Ioane Teitiota in his appeal of a New Zealand court removal order, it has not ruled out that others could claim refugee status because of climate change. Mr. Teitiota claimed that the government of New Zealand violated his right to life after it forced him to move back to Kiribati in 2015. Mr. Teitiota is originally from the island of Tarawa in the Republic of Kiribati. He and his wife left for New Zealand in 2007 because of overcrowding caused by rising sea levels. The influx of people from lower lying areas strained the island's resources, and the general health of the population has deteriorated due to increased food insecurity. Tarawa lacks ground level sources of fresh water, and what underground sources exist have been depleted by the population increase or contaminated by the rising sea levels. 60% of the population receives fresh water from rationed supplies, while those living in homes constructed out of more permanent materials can use rainwater catchment system. The UN ruled that the conditions on Tarawa do not amount to a significant enough threat on his life to define him as a "refugee" according to the standards laid out in the Refugee Convention. According to the UN, despite the conditions on Tarawa, Mr. Teitiota still has access to food and potable water, and he is not physically in danger of violence. As such, New Zealand did not act arbitrarily when it order the removal of Mr. Teitiota and his family. According to the UN, Tarawa, and the rest of the Republic of Kiribati will remain inhabitable for the next 10 to 15 years, which gives Kiribati plenty of time to alleviate, if not fix, the situation with international help. It is clear that under more severe circumstances, the UN may have decided in Mr. Teitiota's favor instead. While the decision is not binding, it does offer a guide post for countries to refer to in the future when handling similar cases.

item.title: UN Human Rights Committee finds climate change can violate right to life---HOLD
item.dc:creator: cstephens
item.content:encoded: The UN Human Rights Committee found Monday that the impacts of climate change can violate one's right to life. The ruling could impact countries seeking to deport individuals who are seeking asylum on the basis that their home country is no longer habitable given the effects of climate change. Under Article 6 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, every human being has an inherent right to life. This right may not be arbitrarily deprived. The specific facts of Monday's case involve Ioane Teitiota, a man from Kiribati who sought asylum in New Zealand. Teitiota was deported to Kiribati after his application had been rejected. He appealed to the UN Human Rights Committee, asserting that Kiribati is no longer habitable. The island faces farming and water issues from climate change. The UN Human Rights Committee rejected his argument. However, the Committee wrote that the effects of climate change could impact one's right to life. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, provided that the issue will only get worse, as millions of individuals could be forced out of their homes due to the impacts of climate change. The UN Human Rights Committee signaled in its ruling that international action will be necessary to solve this problem. The ruling provided, "The Committee is of the view that without robust national and international efforts, the effects of climate change in receiving states may expose individuals to a violation of their rights under articles 6 or 7 of the Covenant."

item.dc:creator: gkolencik
item.content:encoded: Russian lawmakers on Thursday quickly gave preliminary approval to a slew of constitutional changes, but not without some controversy. The approved changes come one week after President Vladimir Putin delivered his State of the Nation speech in which he discussed the constitutional amendment changes. The Duma, the lower level of Russia’s house of parliament, approved of those changes, with the likelihood of passing sometime in February. Although the proposed changes were presented as being for the purpose of strengthening the power of Parliament and Russian democracy, many fear that Putin’s true intention is to remain president beyond the end of his term, which would otherwise conclude in 2024.

item.title: Ninth Circuit strikes down Arizona voting restriction law---HOLD
item.dc:creator: cstephens
item.content:encoded:
The Ninth Circuit struck down Arizona's H.B. 2023 Monday, finding a violation of the Voting Rights Act and Fifteenth Amendment. The court stated that two provisions were invalid.
H.B. 2023 incorporated an "out-of-precinct" policy (OOP), which allowed county officials to discard ballots if discovered that the ballot was submitted at a non-designated precinct. Additionally, the law prohibited voters from collecting and submitting completed ballots for other voters.
Proponents of the law argue that it is necessary to protect against voter fraud. Opponents assert that the law is racially motivated and designed to reduce voter turnout. Specifically in this case, the court discussed a video that allegedly motivated Arizona representatives to pass H.B. 2023. The court wrote
The LaFaro Video provides even stronger evidence of racial motivation. Maricopa County Republican Chair LaFaro produced a video showing 'a man of apparent Hispanic heritage'—volunteer with a get-out-the-vote organization—apparently dropping off ballots at a polling place. LaFaro's voice-over narration included unfounded statements, 'that the man was acting to stuff the box' and that LaFaro 'knew that he was a thug.'
The court cited the discriminatory impact and alleged racially intent when it found the law invalid. It is unclear if the case will be appealed to the US Supreme Court.

item.title: FCC Commissioner calls on FCC to investigate robocalls in Texas Primary
item.dc:creator: ahursh
item.content:encoded: FCC commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel stated on Twitter Tuesday that the agency had received complaints about robocalls spreading misinformation during primary voting in Texas. "The FCC needs to investigate. Now," Rosenworcel wrote. A public advocacy group called the Lawyers' Committee on Civil Rights has filed a formal complaint describing reports it received on Tuesday from voters in Texas. Automated calls had been misinforming people, the group said, about the date of the Texas primary, telling them Democratic votes should be cast on Wednesday, instead of Tuesday when the primary was actually held. Federal law and FCC regulations do not allow automated or pre-recorded political phone calls to be sent to cell phones. The FCC maintains a website with tips for consumers about avoiding robocalls, providing directions for how to complain to the agency about the practice as well. In the political context, robotic calls and pre-recorded messages can be particularly onerous when used to sow confusion about things like voting rules and polling locations. "The Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights Under Law was one of the first civil rights group to actively urge the FCC to launch an investigation into the fearmongering and hate-fueled robocalls to spread misinformation and cause harm," notes a statement from the group's president ahead of the primary election cycle that began this year.

item.title: World Health Organization to convene to emergency committee on coronavirus---HOLD
item.dc:creator: vnegron
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday the World Health Organization (WHO) sent out a statement that they will convene an emergency committee to determine if the coronavirus constitutes a public health emergency. The virus was first found in China where over a period of five days 44 cases were found with people affected. They have yet to ascertain the origin of the virus but as of January 20th, there have been reported cases in Japan, Thailand and the Republic of Korea. This rapid spread and increase in numbers, 282 cases with six deaths and twelve patients in critical condition, has caused the WHO to want to quickly ascertain the damage before the incidents become more severe.

item.title: Mississippi Supreme Court reinstates a life-without-parole sentence for child conviction---HOLD
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha
item.content:encoded:
The Mississippi Supreme Court reinstated a life-without-parole child conviction Thursday. This ruling seemingly contradicts a 2012 US Supreme Court ruling that banned mandatory life-without-parole sentencing for convicts under the age of eighteen. However, the Mississippi Supreme Court found that, though the 2012 US Supreme Court ruling prohibited such mandatory sentences, the US Supreme Court ruling still allowed for life-without-parole sentences after considering youth-related mitigating factors. Justice Maxwell of the Mississippi Supreme Court explained the controversial decision:
Taking into account all these [youth-related mitigating factors], the trial court concluded [the defendant] was one of those rare juveniles who is irreparably corrupt. According to the trial court, “[t]he heinousness of his crime, the expert testimony from his trial and resentencing hearing, and his lack of remorse reveal an individual with a broken moral compass,” whose “prison records confirm his unwavering contempt for authority and discipline in even the most restricted environments.” Unwilling to the take the risk that [the defendant]’s expert admitted would be involved in allowing him parole, the trial court resentenced to [the defendant] to four consecutive terms of life in prison without parole.
In 1994, a Mississippi trial court originally sentenced the defendant in the Mississippi Supreme Court case to death on four counts of capital murder. The defendant was sixteen when he murdered four family members with help from a neighbor. However, in 2005 the US Supreme Court ruled the death penalty unconstitutional for persons convicted under the age of eighteen. As such, the Mississippi Supreme Court ordered a Mississippi trial court to resentence the defendant to life without parole. This controversial ruling will undoubtedly fuel the ongoing debate over child convictions and sentencing in the United States, since the US Supreme Court has trended towards more merciful sentencing for children in recent decades.

item.title: Judge favors University of Iowa in lawsuit alleging mishandled sexual assault report---HOLD
item.dc:creator: vbesteman
item.content:encoded: District Court Judge Samantha Gronewald ruled in favor of the University of Iowa on Monday in a lawsuit alleging the university's mishandling of a student's sexual assault report. The ruling comes as a response to a 2017 lawsuit by Samantha Lange, a Ph.D. student in the university's Department of Political Science. Lange started with the department in 2010 and her report claimed that she was sexually assaulted in 2012 and 2013 by another student in the program. The student admitted to Lange's assault claims and the university responded by administering a no-contact order between the two and placing a three-year suspension on the assailant. The suspension was appealed and later reduced to one year. According to Lange, the university failed to accommodate her following her sexual assault, instead responding with discriminatory and retaliatory measures. After taking the 2013-2014 academic year off, Lange and her assaulter continued to work in the same building. Lange argued that this made the no-contact order hard to maintain and that the arrangement burdened her with the responsibility of communicating her use of the facilities, prolonging the trauma associated with the event. Lange's lawsuit argued that the university "placed obstacles in her educational and employment paths, while her perpetrator was supported in his academic, research, educational, extracurricular, and other programs and activities by the University and the Political Science Department at her expense." The university requested summary judgment on the matter in December 2019, suggesting that Lange failed to "exhaust her administrative remedies" and to prove that "she suffered an adverse employment action."  The court ultimately agreed with the university, ruling that Lange did not show that it was "deliberately indifferent" to her situation. Gronewald held that Lange was unable to prove that she had been passed over for any positions in favor of a student who did not not file a sexual assault report. Despite the summary judgment ruling, Lange has expressed a desire to continue to raise awareness related to the backlash that survivors of similar experiences face following the reporting of their assailants.

item.title: WHO declares Global Public Health Emergency
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: The Director General of the WHO, Tedros Adhanom, declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on Thursday. This is only the fifth time since its creation that the WHO has made such a declaration. In a statement released by the Emergency Committee, the WHO outlined steps it advised countries to take to prevent further spread of the virus. The Committee voiced their approval of the leadership and commitment displayed by Chinese officials since the outbreak. They also praised China's quick identification of the virus and its sharing of that information with other countries. The Committee advised the WHO to utilize its network of epidemiological experts to determine the best ways of containing the virus globally. It also advised the WHO to increase their support in regions and countries that may be particularly vulnerable or lack the necessary medical equipment. The Committee advised countries to prepare to contain the virus, and if necessary take measures to restrict the movements of their citizens. Though, such restrictions should only be implemented if there is a high likelihood that they will be effective in containing the spread of the virus. More a more detailed list of steps the Committee advises countries to take, and relevant technical specifications can be found on the WHO's website. There have been 134 confirmed cases in 23 countries outside China. As of Saturday, there were eight confirmed cases in the United States. The CDC has issued a two week quarantine for anyone who recently visited the Hubei province, and health screenings for anyone returning from China. This is the first time the CDC has issued quarantine orders since the 1960s. On January 23, 2020 the State Department ordered the evacuation of all non-emergency personnel and their families from the U.S. Consulate in Wuhan. The State Department issued a "Do Not Travel" advisory for China on Friday.

item.title: Westpec hit with a second class action---HOLD
item.dc:creator: vnegron
item.content:encoded: On Monday Australian lender Westpec Banking Co was hit with a class-action lawsuit in the US. The suit is the second they have received in the past weeks. The suit is on behalf of investors who invested between 2015 and November of 2019. Westpec has been in financial trouble recently with Australian authorities charging them with breaching anti-money laundering laws. The US lawsuits stem from similar claims including inappropriate due diligence when dealing with Southeast Asian lenders and failing to monitor terrorism financing risks. Westpec has yet to make a statement about the lawsuits.

item.title: Peruvian woman demands right to die with dignity
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: A terminally ill Peruvian woman, Ana Estrada, filed a lawsuit against Peru's Ministry of Health and other agencies on Friday. In her lawsuit, Ms. Estrada asks them to not enforce a law that punishes doctors who aid terminally ill patients in ending their lives. Violation of the law carries a three year prison sentence. Ms. Estrada also asks the Peruvian government to recognize patients' right to die with dignity. This is not the first attempt to legalize euthanasia in Peru. Congressman Roberto Angulo Alvarez proposed a law legalizing euthanasia in 2015, but it did not succeed. Mr. Angulo Alvarez argued that the law promoted individual freedom and human dignity, while preventing unnecessary pain and suffering. Ms. Estrada, who was diagnosed with polymyositis as a child and confined to a wheel chair at 20 years old, led a normal life until her condition deteriorated in 2015. Since then she has been confined to a hospital bed and relies on tubes in her stomach and throat to eat and breath. Euthanasia is legal in over twenty countries, with some allowing "active" euthanasia, "passive" euthanasia, physician assisted suicide or some combination there of. Euthanasia, in general, means that a physician takes the steps to end a patient's life. "Active" euthanasia refers to physicians administering a lethal substance, while "passive" is more along the lines of stopping medical treatment. Physician assisted suicide means that the patient takes the final steps to end their life instead of the physician. Cases like Ms. Estrada's center on whether not people should be allowed to choose to end their lives if they are suffering from a terminal illness, and what exactly defines "terminal" illness. A Colombian court case from 1997 permits euthanasia for people suffering from specific illnesses like cancer, but not degenerative diseases like Alzheimer's. Other countries outlaw euthanasia but permit physician assisted suicide. It remains to be seen whether or not the Peruvian Supreme Court will hear the case.

item.title: TEST PA joins list of states suing JUUL Labs for marketing e-cigarettes to adolescents and teens in a fight against the growing use in schools
item.dc:creator: dklapper
item.content:encoded:
On Monday, the Pennsylvania Attorney General filed a complaint, suing JUUL Labs for marketing their e-cigarette products to teens and adolescents. JUUL Labs, Inc. developed an e-cigarette product, the Juul e-cigarette (colloquially named, "Juul") in 2016. Following its exponential growth between 2017 and 2018, vaping rates among minors doubled from 11.7% to 20.8%. Vaping rates grew again in October 2019 to 27.5%, mirroring a rise in Juul sales, while other e-cigarette brands experienced stable sales. Juul Pods, the interchangeable nicotine cartridge used in Juuls, are sold in a variety of flavors that specifically appeal to children. Most notably, Peanut Jam, Spicy Watermelon, Cinnamon Snap, Lemon Poppyseed, Apple Cran, Apple Crumble, Mixed Berry, Crisp Pear, Cool Mint, Coco Mint, Fruit Medley, Crème Brulee, Cool Cucumber, Mango, and Classic Menthol. The Attorney General enumerated six main, factual arguments in his complaint:
  1.  By its design, Juul is similar to cigarettes
  2.  Juul contributes to the national nicotine epidemic (announced by the FDA and Surgeon General) because it optimizes nicotine delivery and absorption, which increases the chance to cause dependence
  3.  Juul is design and marketed in a way that specifically appeals to minors
  4.  JUUL Labs' "Switch Campaign" markets the product as safe, violating FDA prohibitions against such campaigns
  5.  Juul was sold in a way accessible to minors.
  6.  Juul has harmed Pennsylvanians, specifically youth, and will continue to cause harm unless the court acts
The Attorney General also listed six legal claims:
  1. Violations of the Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Law (UTPCPL)
  2. Public Nuisance
  3. Strict Products Liability
  4. Negligence
  5. Willful Breach of Special Duty
  6. Unjust Enrichment
In the eight exhibits used to support its claims, The Attorney General highlights how the marketing specifically target minors. Multiple pictures show colorful advertisements featuring young adults, resembling ads of young clothing manufacturers. Other images show digital advertisements depicting fruit and colorful imagery, with a Juul or Juul Pod at its center. Other exhibits show social media and email advertisements, distinguishing Juul from Big Tobacco and how Juul is, "on a mission to eliminate cigarettes." A few articles were also submitted as exhibits, calling Juul the "iPhone" or "Lambo[rghini]" of e-cigarettes. The Attorney General also submitted a warning letter from the Center for Tobacco Products in Maryland. The letter warns Juul to change its marketting, noting statutory violations and demanding Juul complies with state and federal regulations. JUUL Labs, Inc. has yet to respond to the complaint.

item.title: TEST- Payton's first JURIST post
item.dc:creator: psmith
item.content:encoded: Hi my name is Payton this is a test post and I'm doing jurist.

item.title: TEST Texas attempts to block California from banning state-funded travel
item.dc:creator: tklan
item.content:encoded: On Monday, Texas filed a lawsuit asking the Supreme Court to overturn California's ban on state-funded travel to 11 states that they found to have discriminatory policies against the LGBTQ community. The bill explicitly included Texas in the ban, citing a need to protect civil rights and combat discrimination. This ban came in response to Texas legislation that allows adoption facilities to decline placements with same-sex couples based on their religious beliefs. About 25% of the adoption agencies in Texas are the private facilities affected by this bill. These agencies claim that the bill will protect them from being sued for refusing to work with single, gay, or non-Christian parents. While Texas claims that this bill does not prohibit particular groups from adopting, California has characterized it as state-funded discrimination that offers religious freedom beyond that required by the First Amendment. Texas has now condemned California's ban for fostering public adherence to a repugnant ideology, claiming that the ban shows an animus toward religion that is unconstitutional; accordingly, Texas has asked to be excluded from the ban. They have said that California's ban harms businesses in Texas and deprives them of associated tax revenue while secondarily depriving Californians of valuable academic experiences. Texas has further claimed that the travel ban is a relatively ineffective way of targeting their economy compared to similar sanctions. The main argument against California's travel ban is that is violates both the commerce and equal protection clauses of the Constitution by interfering with interstate commerce and discriminating against Texas citizens.

item.title: T-Mobile and Sprint win approval for merger---HOLD
item.dc:creator: jdougherty
item.content:encoded: A federal court in New York approved the merger of T-Mobile and Sprint on Tuesday. Several states led by New York attempted to block the proposed merger between T-Mobile and Sprint, claiming the merger would “substantially lessen competition in the market for retail mobile wireless telecommunication services.” T-Mobile, Sprint, and its investors said the merger would actually increase competition in the industry. The District Court for the Southern District of New York agreed with T-Mobile and Sprint. In his 170-page opinion, Judge Victor Marrero said “antitrust disputes virtually turns the judge into a fortuneteller.” The role of the judge, in this case, is to predict what will happen after a merge occurs. He said the central question in this action is “whether a deeply embedded pattern of commercial conduct closely and publicly associated with a company or executive is likely to be abandoned or substantially altered after a merger, so as to openly embrace a materially conflicting course, especially in the short term.” The Court pulls the thread of this question through its three-part analysis. In the first part, Judge Marrero said that the Plaintiff States had not persuaded the Court that T-Mobile would pursue anticompetitive behavior after the merger. The Court used the competitive environment of the retail mobile wireless telecommunication services industry, which has price-conscious consumers and is deeply tied to the quality of the service. The competitive nature of the industry and T-Mobile’s recent performance does not indicate the New T-Mobile would change its behavior. In the second part, the Court disagrees with the Plaintiff States’ claim that Sprint would continue to be a strong competitor in the market. The Court examines Sprint’s recent downward trajectory and debt and determines that it is unlikely that Sprint would remain a strong competitor. The Court states that “Sprint’s network and product offerings have been distinguished for years for poor operational quality and negative customer perception.” The company was in financial turmoil and brought in a new CEO to turnaround the company. Sprint’s executive team said the merger was the best option for the company. Finally, the Court disagreed with the Plaintiff States’ evidence that DISH would not enter the wireless services market as a viable competitor. The Court found that the entry by DISH, the commonly known television content provider, into the retail wireless telecommunication services would be the “most prominent” remedy to rebutting the Plaintiff States’ case. The Court found adequate evidence that DISH is well-positioned to enter the market and has plans to do so. DISH, in the short term, would be a viable competitor to the industry dominated by the Verizon, AT&T, and the New T-Mobile. DISH would be the fourth largest of those competitors. If it stands, Judge Marrerro’s decision is a big win for T-Mobile and Sprint. This case falls among the many antitrust disputes. Antitrust critics who believe antitrust enforcement has been too lax in recent years are unlikely to be satisfied by this decision, but there is no indication yet that the decision will be challenged.

item.title: TEST Uber and Postmates denied an injunction against new California gig worker law
item.dc:creator: psmith
item.content:encoded:
A US district court judge ruled against Uber's and Postmates' request for a preliminary injunction against a California law that is aimed at giving wage and benefit protections to people who work as independent contractors. The California law, known as AB 5, was approved by lawmakers in September 2019 and created a three-part test to determine the distinction between an independent contractor and an employee. To hire a worker as an independent contractor, the job description must satisfy the "ABC" test, establishing:
"that the worker (a) is 'free from the control and direction of the hirer in connection with the performance of the work, both under the contract for the performance of such work and in fact'; (b) 'performs work that is outside the usual course of the hiring entity's business'; and (c) is 'customarily engaged in an independently established trade, occupation, or business of the same nature as the work performed for the hiring entity.'"
Uber and Postmates are opposed to AB 5 and argue that the law targets them as "gig companies," treating them differently from similarly situated groups. The companies contend that the new rules will make it harder for them to classify their workers as independent contractors rather than employees. App-based companies like Uber and Postmates argue this legislation compromises the flexibility they offer to their workforce. Judge Dolly M. Gee ruled, "the balance of equities and the public interest weigh in favor of permitting the State to enforce this legislation." Because the statute rationally furthers "a legitimate state interest," the court determined AB 5 did not target gig economy companies in violation of the Equal Protection Clause. The exploitation of workers that lends to "the erosion of the middle class and income inequality" is the asserted interest being protected by AB 5.

item.title: HRW: Australia should pass new law to target human rights abusers---HOLD
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: Human Rights Watch ("HRW") last Thursday submitted Australian Parliament's Human Rights Subcommittee a submission that inquires the government to join others and pass a new law that sanctions human rights abusers. The submission reasons that targeted sanctions are "an appropriate and useful foreign policy tool to press accountability for serious abuses, and to raise the cost of human rights violations, by denying abusers both entry to and assets in foreign countries where they seek to travel or do business." Only individuals, rather than entire government will be sanctioned by the said law. The submission examines the experience of Global Magnitsky-style laws, such as the US Global Magnitsky Act, based on HRW's experience in different countries and whether such law would benefit Australia. "A specific law would create a clear, transparent process for members of parliament and civil society to present information to the government, and compels the foreign ministry to closely examine serious cases of human rights abuse." Certain drawbacks of Magnitsky-style laws are mentioned in the submission, such as the inconsistency in applying the law to officials from different countries due to political reasons. Yet the submission emphasized that Australia government should join the other countries to sanction human rights violations.

item.title: High Court of Australia rules that Aboriginal Australians cannot be deported as non-citizens---HOLD
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded: The High Court of Australia ruled 4-3 on Monday that Aboriginal Australians cannot be deported for reason of being non-citizens. The case concerned two Aboriginal men who were born outside Australia, and who faced deportation orders because they each had a criminal conviction. The Commonwealth argued that since the two men were not Australian citizens, the minister for Home Affairs had the power to deport them. Under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution, the Commonwealth has the power to make laws relating to "naturalisation and aliens". Lawyers for the two men argued that even though they are not citizens, as native people of Australia they cannot be considered "aliens" and therefore cannot be deported. Their argument rested on the connection to the land inherent in an indigenous non-citizen's ancestry, and a resulting implication of belonging. People will have to be able to prove their Aboriginality as a question of fact in order to be disqualified from treatment as an alien. One of the men in this case is a native title holder, and his Aboriginal ancestry was therefore not an issue. The other man is not a native title holder, and the majority could not reach a finding on whether he qualified as an alien under the law. The decision implies a new legal category which would encompass non-citizen Aboriginals, that of a "non-citizen, non-alien." The three dissenting judges agreed with the Commonwealth's argument that this special category was not valid. This decision will protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians who were born outside the country, recognizing their right to to remain in the land to which they have an important connection.

item.title: Parents of cancer patients sue Mexico government over medication shortages---HOLD
item.dc:creator: msullivan
item.content:encoded: Lawyer Andrea Rocha has filed lawsuits against the government of Mexico on behalf of more than sixty children and their parents. Most of these children are fighting cancer, and they have not been able to receive the medication needed in the past few months due to a shortage. Mexican president, Lopez Obrador, has blamed the shortage on "Mexican pharmaceutical distributors who were resisting the procurement changes, along with hospital officials who [] hoarded medicines and supply issues from drug companies in China and India." Protests led by parents of affected children have increased in Mexico City over the past few weeks. The president ran for office on the platform that he would reform the "corrupt" healthcare system and promised fee-free service under his administration. Parent protestors believe it is that very mission that is causing the shortage of cancer-fighting drugs in the first place.

item.title: Mexico legislators vote to increase penalties for femicide and minor abuse
item.dc:creator: tklan
item.content:encoded:
On Tuesday, Mexico's Chamber of Deputies approved a proposal to amend the Federal Criminal Code to increase the maximum sentence for femicide to 65 years instead of 60. The amendment further increased the minimum sentence from 40 years to 45.
Additionally, the proposed amendment increased the prison sentence for sexual abuse of minors to a maximum of 18 years and a minimum of 10. Previous sentences were limited to 6-13 years. The legislation came in response to public outcry following the murder of a young woman and discovery of the body of a young girl shortly thereafter.
These changes to the Federal Criminal Code were approved with 415 votes in favor and one opposed. Next, the proposal will go to the Senate for final approval and enactment.

item.title: Appeals court rules Florida amendment that bars certain felons from re-enfranchisement over fines and fees unconstitutional
item.dc:creator: psmith
item.content:encoded:
A federal appeals court has ruled Florida's provision that restricted felons who cannot pay legally financial obligations from voting as unconstitutional. In a unanimous ruling, the three-judge panel affirmed a lower court's finding that Florida's Senate Bill 7066 (SB 7066) violates the Constitution's Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
The case follows Florida's passage of Amendment 4, which automatically restored voting rights to ex-felons who had completed all terms of their sentences. After the passage of Amendment 4, the Florida legislature passed SB 7066 as part of the Amendment. The law was interpreted to include payment of all legal financial obligations ("LFOs") such as fines, fees, and restitution before a felon would be eligible for re-enfranchisement.
A group of seventeen ex-felons brought suit, arguing that because the LFO requirement punishes those who cannot pay more harshly than those who can by denying them the right to vote, that the law is therefore unconstitutional. Each plaintiff is a felon who has alleged that he or she would be eligible for re-enfranchisement under Amendment 4 but for their genuine inability to pay the LFO obligations.
"It is undeniable that the LFO requirement punishes those who cannot pay more harshly than those who can. Denying access to the franchise to those genuinely unable to pay solely on account of wealth does not survive heightened scrutiny," the judges wrote in their opinion. The judges reasoned the punishment is linked directly to the fact of the plaintiffs' wealth or lack thereof. Therefore the plaintiffs are punished more harshly than other felons who committed the same crimes solely because of their inability to pay.
The court recognized Florida's interest in continuing the disenfranchisement of these plaintiffs for criminal deterrence, punishment, and debt collection purposes. However, balancing the State's argument with the interests of the plaintiffs, the court held the State has adequate alternatives to promote its interests.

item.title: New Hampshire passes 3 bills to grant immunity to reporters of crimes---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: New Hampshire House of Representatives on Thursday passed three bills that grant immunity to those who report crimes from being prosecuted themselves, including alcohol violation, prostitution and possession of a controlled drug. House Bill 1351 provides immunity from arrest or prosecution for alcoholic beverage violations for a person under 21 years of age who "in good faith and in a timely manner" contacts medical or emergency services as a result of an alcohol overdose, either for himself or for another person in the similar situation. This bill is not a defense to driving under influence charges pursuant to RSA 265-A. House Bill 1656-FN provides immunity from prosecution for prostitution for a person reporting to law enforcement that such person or another person is the victim of a sexual assault. The report must be reporting the initial crime to law enforcement and assisting law enforcement to identify the alleged perpetrator, and does not include further cooperation in prosecution. House Bill 1271-FN provides immunity from criminal charges for possession of a controlled drug for a person who reports "in good faith and in a timely manner" to law enforcement that such person or another person has been the victim of a violent crime, if the evidence for the charge was gained as a proximate result of the request for medical assistance or the report to law enforcement.

item.title: Ontario judge rules parts of Canada's prostitution law are unconstitutional---HOLD
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded: An Ontario Court judge ruled on Friday that three parts of Canada's prostitution laws violate the Charter of Rights and Freedom. Judge Thomas McKay ruled that the country's ban on advertising sexual services violates the Charter's right to freedom of expression, and that the bans on procuring and materially benefiting from the services violates the Charter's guarantee of "security of the person." Canada's laws follows what is known as the Nordic Model, which means that the purchase of sex is criminalized but the sale of sex is not. The ruling resulted in the staying of charges against London, Ontario couple Tiffany Harvey and Hamad Anwar, who ran the website Fantasy World Escorts until it was shut down in 2015. John Cassells, an anti-human-trafficking specialist with Christian mission organization SIM Canada, characterized the decision as "protecting pimps" and stated that it needed to be appealed. If the Crown decides to appeal the ruling, it would have to be upheld in the Toronto Court of Appeals in order for any laws to be nullified. The couple's lawyer, James Lockyer, stated that the ruling would be important for the safety of sex workers, enabling them to set up co-operatives to protect each other and use advertising to screen clients before meeting. He and the couple's other lawyer, Jack Gemmell, argued that Canada's 2014 prostitution laws drive sex workers underground and increase the risk of exploitation by prohibiting such measures. In his written ruling, Judge McKay agreed that the provisions are drafted to broadly and have the effect of exposing sex workers to an increased risk of exploitation and violence.
item.category: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

item.title: TEST: Supreme Court will hear Affordable Care Act case.
item.dc:creator: amonti
item.content:encoded: On Monday, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a challenge to the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) individual mandate. The Court is combining two petitions. Both petitions requested the Court to review the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals' decision to strike down the mandate. California, joined by other states, petitioned in support of the individual mandate. Texas, along with other states, petitioned against the mandate and in support of the 5th Circuit Court's decision. The Supreme Court will likely hear oral arguments from both parties next fall. The Supreme Court will answer three questions. First, whether Texas (along with the other states) has a right to sue and challenge the mandate in court. Second, whether the individual mandate is constitutional in light of Congress's 2017 amendment, which adjusted the penalty for choosing not to purchase insurance to zero.  Third, if the mandate is unconstitutional, whether it can be separated from the rest of the ACA. If the individual mandate cannot be separated, then the ACA will likely be struck down entirely. In 2012, the Supreme Court first addressed the ACA's individual mandate. The Court decided the mandate was constitutional because Congress has the power to impose taxes, and the penalty is a tax. In 2017, Congress amended the ACA to change the penalty to zero. This amendment has sparked new constitutional challenges. Texas argues the penalty for choosing not to buy insurance is no longer a tax because it is zero. Since the penalty is no longer a tax, the individual mandate cannot be constitutional. Also, Texas claims the individual mandate cannot be separated from the ACA, so the entire law must be struck down. California argues the mandate is constitutional because it still leaves individuals the choice to purchase insurance even though the penalty is zero. Overall, the Supreme Court's decision could have a significant impact on the ACA. The Court will likely hear arguments in fall and issue a decision sometime in 2021.

item.title: TEST: Utah Senate voted on bill banning elective abortions if Roe v. Wade is overturned
item.dc:creator: amonti
item.content:encoded: The Utah Senate voted on Monday to pass SB174, which bans elective abortions at any stage of a woman's pregnancy with limited exceptions. However, the bill will only become effective if binding authority - the Supreme Court - overturns Roe v. Wade. Roe v. Wade is a landmark case because the Supreme Court decided the right to privacy included a woman's choice to have an abortion. The Court's opinion used the three trimesters of pregnancy to explain when a State may regulate abortions. Currently, States may regulate abortions in certain situations during the second and third trimester. The bill can only become effective if the Supreme Court reverses Roe v. Wade because it regulates abortions at any stage of pregnancy. The bill prohibits abortions, except in cases where the mother's life is threatened, the unborn fetus has a severe brain abnormality, or when the pregnancy is a result of incest or rape. The rape must be reported to the police for the exception to apply. Also, two physicians must confirm the severe brain abnormality for the exception to apply. The bill also penalizes physicians and clinics that perform abortions in violation of the bill's restrictions; those that violate the bill are guilty of a second-degree felony. The bill does not apply to the removal of a dead unborn child or ectopic pregnancy. Now, the bill is heading to the State House of Representatives.

item.title: Federal appeals court affirms 'diet' label does not deceptively promise weight loss
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded: The US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on Monday ruled that Dr Pepper did not violate California consumer fraud laws by using the word "diet" in its brand name. The complaint stated that consumers were promised by the diet label that the product "would 'assist in weight loss' or at least 'not cause weight gain.'" As support, the complaint included various studies showing the artificial sweetener used in Diet Dr Pepper, aspartame, is linked with weight gain. It further cited dictionary definitions to show that "reasonable consumers understand the word 'diet' to promise assistance in weight loss." Because of the discrepancy between the diet label and the effects, the lawsuit claimed Dr Pepper violated a number of laws including: the California False Advertising Law, the California Consumers Legal Remedies Act, and the California Unfair Competition Law. The court reasoned, though, that diet products are common in the marketplace and are used to distinguish the products as lower calorie than regular counterparts. Dictionary definitions for "diet soft drinks" state that they have fewer calories or utilize calorie-free sweeteners. The term diet does not "promise weight loss, healthy weight management, or other health benefits," and such unreasonable interpretations by consumers do not make the term deceptive.

item.title: Federal judge allows California updated light bulb efficiency standards to take effect
item.dc:creator: cmaas
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the Eastern District of California on Tuesday denied a motion by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association (NEMA) and the American Lighting Association (ALA) for a temporary restraining order against the California Energy Commission (CEC) to block updated light bulb efficiency standards. NEMA and ALA filed a complaint against the CEC and its Chairman and Commissioner on December 13 challenging CEC's application of a 45-lumens-per-watt energy conservation standard to five types of general service lamps (GSLs) with new definitions of GSLs that were to take effect January 1, 2020. NEMA and ALA filed a motion for a temporary restraining order on December 20, and CEC filed an opposition to the motion on December 26. The court held a telephonic hearing with the parties on December 27. NEMA and ALA claimed that the CEC's issuance of regulations, which incorporate different federal definitions of GSLs and apply a 45-lumens-per-watt efficiency standard to five different types of lamps, violates the federal Energy Policy and Conservation Act (EPCA). Incandescent reflector lamps, intermediate base incandescent lamps, candelabra base incandescent reflector lamps, rough service incandescent lamps and vibration service incandescent lamps were subject to federal energy conservation standards that conflicted with the new standard California sought to impose. NEMA and ALA claimed, as a result of the these new regulations, that manufacturers of these five lamps will be "unable effectively to meet their customers' needs in California and across the country." However, the judge found that NEMA and ALA did not establish the factors necessary for the court to grant the motion for a temporary restraining order, nor had they "established a likelihood of success on the merits of their claim." The court found that the CEC operated as allowed by EPCA exceptions. The CEC exercised its authority under California's Warren-Alquist Act and provided notice of its intent to adopt federal definitions of GSLs then in effect in April 2017. After a rule making and public notice and comment period, the CEC adopted those definitions on November 13. Because of this, the judge found that NEMA and ALA had not met their burden and their motion was denied. The new regulations went into effect on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump signs act to combat robocalls
item.dc:creator: cmaas
item.content:encoded: The White House announced Monday that US President Donald Trump signed S 151, the Pallone-Thune Telephone Robocall Abuse Criminal Enforcement and Deterrence Act (Pallone-Thune TRACED Act), into law. The Pallone-Thune TRACED Act authorizes the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to issue additional civil penalties for intentional violations of restrictions on the use of automated telephone equipment.  The FCC was also directed to require voice service providers to offer call authentication technologies. Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham stated: "American families deserve control over their communications, and this legislation will update our laws and regulations to stiffen penalties, increase transparency, and enhance government collaboration to stop unwanted solicitation." As part of the act, the FCC is required to publish a report on private-led efforts to trace the origin of suspected unlawful robocalls and the participation of voice service providers in these efforts. This report is to be published within a year after the law's enactment, and it will be available on the FCC website.

item.title: Illinois governor pardons 11,017 for cannabis convictions
item.dc:creator: jdougherty
item.content:encoded:
Illinois Governor JB Pritzker on Tuesday granted 11,017 pardons for individuals convicted of misdemeanor cannabis offenses involving less than 30 grams. The expungements involved Illinoisans in 92 counties. The landmark bipartisan Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, signed by the governor in June, provided paths to relief for more the 700,000 cannabis-related arrest and conviction records. While Illinois is the eleventh state in the country to legalize cannabis, it is the first to legalize recreational cannabis for adults through its legislature, rather than voter initiatives. In a statement announcing the expungements, Pritzker said:
Tomorrow when adult-use cannabis becomes legal, pay attention to the fact that we are beginning to accomplish four very important things: We are ending the 50-year long war on cannabis. We are restoring rights to many tens of thousands of Illinoisans. We are bringing regulation and safety to a previously unsafe and illegal market. And we are creating a new industry that puts equity at its very core.
The pardon process looks different for various offenses. The Prisoner Review Board reviews cannabis convictions for up to 30 grams not associated with violent offenses for accuracy and then forwards them to the governor for pardon consideration. There are 116,000 records eligible for expungement through this process. Individuals, civil legal aid organizations, and the state's attorneys can file motions to vacate for cannabis offenses up to 500 grams. There are approximately 34,000 records eligible through this process. Arrest records that did not result in a conviction of up to 30 grams will automatically by expunged, so long as the arrest is not associated with a violent offense. There are approximately 572,000 arrest records eligible for expungement through this process. Illinois Lieutenant Governor Juliana Stratton said, "Illinois is going where no other state has before, admitting that unjust errors of the war on drugs and giving so many Illinoisans greater opportunities to build good lives for themselves and the people they love." Many more pardons and expungements will come in the next several months.

item.title: California Consumer Privacy Act goes into effect
item.dc:creator: jlusamba
item.content:encoded: The California Consumer Privacy Act went into effect Wednesday. The California Consumer Privacy Act, signed into law by then-governor Jerry Brown in June 2018, was enacted in response to a series of data misuse incidents. The Act aims to protect California residents' online privacy by giving them control over their personal information. It gives California consumers the right to know what personal information businesses are collecting about them, the right to know whether that information is being sold or shared and to whom, the right to forbid those businesses from sharing or selling that personal information, and the right not to be discriminated against for doing so. While the Act protects only California residents, some companies have decided to extend the Act's protections to consumers nationwide. Now that the Act has gone into effect and companies have had to update their privacy policies, what remains to be seen is whether other states will also enact similar data privacy laws.

item.title: Trump sings bill to eliminate rape kit backlog
item.dc:creator: jlusamba
item.content:encoded: US President Trump on Monday signed a bill that will help eliminate rape kit backlogs throughout the country. HR 777, also known as the Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act, authorizes up to $151,000,000 in funding per year to state and local governments to process and test DNA evidence. The Act renews the Debbie Smith Act, which had expired at the end of 2019. The initial Debbie Smith Act was enacted in 2004 and had been reauthorized twice (in 2008 and 2014) before this latest reauthorization. Unlike the original Debbie Smith Act, the Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act prioritizes testing of DNA evidence in rape kits. The Act aims to eliminate the backlog of untested and unanalyzed DNA evidence in rape kits, thus ensuring that sexual assault perpetrators are prosecuted. The Act also funds DNA training and education programs and is valid until 2024.

item.title: Federal judge temporarily blocks parts of New York farm worker law
item.dc:creator: jlusamba
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the Western District of New York on Tuesday temporarily blocked parts of a New York farm workers law from going into effect. Judge Lawrence Vilardo issued a temporary injunction that prevents parts of the Farm Laborers Fair Labor Practices Act from going into effect until a final decision is rendered on the issue. The Act, which was intended to go into effect on January 1, 2020, gives farm workers the right to unionize, the right to at least one day of rest every week and the right to overtime pay of at least one and a half times the regular rate of pay if the farm worker chooses to work on their day of rest or works for more than 60 hours per week. However, on December 30, the Northeast Dairy Producers and the New York State Vegetable Growers Association filed a suit to block the Act from going into effect. The injunction temporarily blocks three parts of the Act from going into effect, namely the part that requires that supervisory agricultural employees and agricultural employees distantly related to the employer be treated as farm workers entitled to the rights granted by the Act, the part that prevents employers from changing family and supervisory employees' pay on seven days notice, and the part that imposes criminal liability for violations of those family and supervisory employees provisions. A hearing is planned on January 24, and then the judge will render a final decision on the case.

item.title: Federal judge denies drug companies' attempt to block California's 'reverse payment' law
item.dc:creator: jdougherty
item.content:encoded: A judge for the US District Court for the Eastern District of California court on Tuesday denied a motion by brand-name drug companies to halt the implementation of a California bill that would stop "reverse payments" to generic drug companies. The bill in question is Assembly Bill 824 (AB 824), which seeks to stop "reverse payment" settlement agreements between brand-name drug companies and generic drug companies during patent infringement claims. The California legislature sought to address these reverse payments because it sees them as anti-competitive and unlawful. The reverse payment scheme arises after a brand-name drug company files a new prescription drug application to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and receives approval to market it. The new prescription drug application is a long, expensive and comprehensive process. After the brand-name company files the new drug application, a generic company can file a less intensive, abbreviated application with the FDA, but must assure the FDA that it will not infringe on any patents. The generic company's assurance that it will not infringe on any patents is called a "Paragraph IV Certification." The Paragraph IV Certification is per se patent infringement, and the brand name company often brings suit against the generic drug manufacturer. This suit often results in the brand name drug company paying the generic drug company to keep its drug off the market for an agreed-upon period of time. AB 824 seeks to stop these types of settlements and "ensure that a brand name drug company cannot continue to enforce an otherwise weak patent against generics through these reverse patent settlements." The plaintiff, a nonprofit association of the brand-name drug companies, was denied the motion for an injunction by Judge Troy Nunley. The plaintiff attempted to block the implementation of the bill by stating that the bill violated the commerce clause, was preempted by federal law, was invalid due to excessive fines, and violated due process. The court stated that "Plaintiff has failed to establish a likelihood of success on the merits of any of these claims and as a result, the Court finds a preliminary injunction is inappropriate at this time." Many of the arguments failed because there was no specific instance in which AB 824 was applied. This case might have been premature and seems ripe for another case after AB 824 is implemented.

item.title: For-profit prison company sues California over law ending use of private prisons
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded: GEO Group, a Florida-based security firm that operates a number of private prions and detainment centers across the US, sued California on Monday after the state passed a law aimed at ending the use of private prisons. The California legislature overwhelmingly passed Assembly Bill 32 (AB 32) in early October, barring the state from entering into new contracts or modifying existing contracts with for-profit prison companies starting in 2020. In addition, the bill prohibits the operation of any for-profit detention centers in the state after 2028. GEO Group alleged in their complaint that AB 32's total prohibition on private detention facilities violates the supremacy clause of the US Constitution by barring the federal government from contracting with private security companies to run facilities inside California. GEO Group currently manages seven facilities for the federal government in California, including immigrant detention centers for US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). In the complaint, GEO Group called AB 32 an effort by California to "subvert" the power of the federal government and "undermine the United States government in the exercise of sovereign powers undoubtedly within the supreme sphere of federal action." GEO Group said that AB 32 was aimed primarily at closing facilities run by ICE, stating that it was a "transparent attempt by the state to shut down the federal government’s detention efforts within California’s borders." It says that the supremacy clause makes it illegal for states to regulate the activities of the federal government in this way and that AB 32 is therefore unconstitutional. California Assemblyman Rob Bonta, the primary author of AB 32, tweeted that the lawsuit was "a desperate attempt [to] buy another year of survival [to] pad its corporate profits. ... People and law [are] against [you]." Neither GEO Group nor California Governor Gavin Newsom have made public statements about the lawsuit.

item.title: Turkey passes law authorizing military deployment into Libya
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded: The Grand National Assembly of Turkey passed a bill on Thursday authorizing the government to deploy troops into Libya. The Turkish Parliament held a special session this week to decide whether to authorize President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan to deploy military forces into Libya to support the Government of National Accord (GNA), the United Nations-recognized government of Libya. The GNA has been fending off increasing attacks by military forces under the command of General Khalifa Hifter, who controls the eastern part of the country. The final vote was 325 in favor to 185 against, according to a statement made by Parliament Speaker Mustafa Sentop, with nearly all of the members of opposition parties voting against the proposal. The bill gives Erdoğan the discretion to determine how and when to deploy the Turkish military for a period of one year. US President Donald Trump cautioned Erdoğan from deploying troops to Libya on a phone call Thursday afternoon. According to a transcript of the call obtained by Politico, Trump said that foreign interference had "complicated the situation" in the country. The GNA is officially recognized by the United Nations and supported by Turkey, Qatar and Italy, while Hifter's forces have received aid from Russia, France and the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Pompeo delays trip to Ukraine and other countries to address Iraq protests, sends troops
item.dc:creator: jross
item.content:encoded: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo canceled an upcoming trip to Ukraine and four other countries on Wednesday in order to address the current security concerns in Iraq. In a press statement, the State Department indicated that Pompeo would reschedule the trip to begin on Friday order to "ensure the safety and security of Americans in the Middle East." The cancelation came after protesters broke into the US Embassy in Baghdad on Tuesday. The protesters, who have been linked to Iraq funded militia, smashed into the embassy compound. Upon entering, the protesters set fire to certain parts of the compound and remained there for until being tear gassed by security on Wednesday. After the break in, 750 US troops were deployed to the Middle East. The protests are in response to the US airstrikes in Syria and Iraq that killed more than 24 people on December 29. Among the causalities were members of Kataeb Hezbollah, an organization with ties to larger Shiite militias. Despite the initial cancellation, Pompeo will conduct his visit starting January 3. The original trip to Ukraine, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Cyprus would have included a meeting between Pompeo and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Officially, the meeting was to discuss US aid to Ukraine for defense against Russian influence and general corruption.

item.title: US drone strike kills top Iran military commander
